resources.string: Héctor García-Molina was a Mexican-American computer scientist, as well as a professor of computer science and electrical engineering at Stanford University. He is most known for his work on RAID technology, and his extensive catalog of research. Over his academic career, he advised 57 PhD students, authored or co-authored nine books, and more than 400 journal articles, including refereed conference papers. Notably, he advised Sergey Brin, the co-founder of Google. In his spare time, he taught introductory photography classes at Stanford, as he was also a professional photographer.

Many in Stanford\'s staff claimed that García-Molina was a kind, welcoming man devoted to his students. He was known to consistently share credit to those he worked with, as well as advising many students at Stanford. In his spare time, he would teach CS45N, the introductory photography course at Stanford, to freshmen. He would often loan his cameras to students interested in photography. He also was the official Stanford sports photographer, snapping pictures of his students giving it their all on the field.

García-Molina studied at Stanford in 1975, studying both computer science and electrical engineering. A year later, he would begin studying for his PhD under the advisory of Gio Wiederhold. After earning his PhD, in 1979, García-Molina would join the faculty of Princeton, developing the foundations for a technology called the Redundant Array of Independent Disks, or RAID for short. Afterward, in 1992, he joined the Stanford faculty.

García-Molina has won several awards for his contributions to computer science. A significant achievement of his was being invited to join the board of directors at the Oracle Corporation, which is a position he held until he passed. He also worked with Terry Winograd to launch the Stanford Digital Libraries Project, which developed ways to store and filter many types of information in traditional libraries. In 2007, he won the ICDE Influential Paper Award for his paper "Disk Striping", which would help in the development on RAID storage. He also served at the U.S. President\'s Information Technology Advisory Committee from 1997 to 2001.
